One of the ways we can build finger and overall hand strength for passing/blocking! 

We do these finger plank progressions in BFV in the open hand position. Basically this means the position you'd be in when receiving the ball. We need to be strong enough to withstand the impact from the ball in this position and quickly switch it to concentric (propelling the ball out of your hands). Training the isometric strength in that position doing the planks is a great way to do that. 

Of course there are levels to this and we want to start at the first level like in the video and work our way up. I love other exercises as well, like rice buckets, ExerRing exercises etc where you can build not only the fingers and hand muscles but the forearm as well. This is just one of the ways! It can also be good to strengthen to reduce the likelihood of finger injuries from passing/digging/blocking. Later I'll go over the progressions and explain more.

Level 1 (knees down) can be done for 1-3 sets 5-30 seconds depending on the athlete, phase etc.

Let's get to work!

#volleyball #vball #volleyballtraining #volleyballplayer #volleyballexercise #volleyballlife #volleyballtime #volleyballtips #volleyballscience

For SHORT and LOW passing - Here's something that can help a lot of you!

If an athlete squats to pass out of habit or stoops/reaches and hasn't trained any other movements, then they can be in trouble when faced with more challenging situations. This means almost every ball they get they're doing this. There are times when squatting or other movements to pass this kind of ball is okay but its good to learn to be comfortable in other positions, and kneeling to pass is one of those that's great for overall movement and positioning. It frees us up more to be more versatile, and puts us in a better position to react and move faster to deviations, keeping us in the play.

For some doing the knee drop can be uncomfortable at first, and if it's beceause of hip structure/mobility then you may need work/something else. But eventually you can get used to it and actually be able to move a lot better. I've seen Muserskiy pick up a ball like this, get back up and crush it through the middle. This is one of the reasons why knee pads/sliders are a no brainer to me. If we can be more free and comfortable to get in better positions to pass/dig and get in and out of them faster, that's awesome.

For those struggling with it I recommend just kneeling and getting comfy in that position. Then you can start passing in it. Coming out of it, stepping in to it, speeding it up and so on. You can do this for a lot of knee drop/defensive positions that you find uncomfortable! From the knee drop I can get into different positions too like drop the other knee, slides, sprawls etc. Learning to fall is also one of the foundations we go over with athletes struggling with movements and positions like these.

Keep in mind this is for low, shorts and other scenarios, and there are other movements/positions that are beneficial depending on the situation (low outside midline, midline absorbing with fall back, sprawls etc). Everyone is different and there's a lot more to it!

Let's go.

Working the spike approach using the collapsible hurdles!

Slight lift on the straight leg but still great explosive effort 📈

The hurdles give a good challenge to produce more force rapidly and get over the bar. Landing can be on a softer surface as well. As a side note it can also be a good/different change for mentality when athletes have similar verticals but different touch heights. On the hurdle it can be 35" but on the vertec that can be 10'5" or 11'5" depending on the heights/limb length. This can create a challenging and motivating environment. 

Work the technique and build explosiveness in it through properly progressed and periodized programming. We have spike approach vertical training in our Built For Volleyball online program.

Let's get to work 📈

Reminder that passing, defense, and volleyball are all about angles and how to use them to manipulate the ball. 

A platform is simply anything we can get behind and under the ball. The best passers and defenders are masters at manipulating the ball because they understand how to use their platform to their advantage. They know the outcome of each touch and how to manipulate a ball based on the situation (where they are and where they want it to go). 

They are also master trackers. In order to pass and defend well, you need to be able to track well. Tracking is not just knowing where the ball will land, but also having the best movements engrained depending on the situation. This means that you know how to act based on where the ball will end up, and how you can intercept it before touching the floor while giving a quality pass. 

Too many times I get athletes that want to pass better, and immediately ask about their platform. Of course, this is what contacts the ball, but it may not be the problem. What I find is it's usually their tracking, timing, platform mobility, and/or overall movements patterns/strength. But it may also come down to their understanding of what their platform is. When I coach I help athletes understand what it is they're doing and why they're doing it. When they understand it at a deeper level, they're now moving with purpose. They can feel what it's like, and remember it. But this doesnt mean overthinking, just understanding how they can use their platform. So their platform mechanics are important, but also how you use it, tracking, timing, mobility etc are all factors that go into passing. Passing and defense depend on the ball being tracked, the timing/skill, and understanding your movements and the game will help you ADJUST your actions to different situations.

Of course there are many factors involved and it depends on the athlete and the situation! It needs to be looked at as a whole.

Let's go!

Here's a drill to help with a "patient arm"! 

I talk a lot about hip shoulder and arm separation, well this one assists arm separation. Basically what that means is our ability to have some range between the torso and arm and also be able to separate the movement so that as the torso comes forward, the arm stays back and loaded. When this happens within sequence the arm can then come forward like a whip! 

We have this exercise paired with technique drills in the BFV program! We can use this to "prime" or get a feel for the action and practice actually applying it. It can also strengthen the action.

Now for this we don't need a TON of range, but having some active separation can benefit. The key is having it timed in sequence so that as the torso is just ending, the arm starts coming forward. 

We also don't need a lot of resistance. Just a light band to help assist the delay and help you learn what it feels like to delay the arm, or you can have someone guide the movement for you. Mirror feedback works great too. I also like holding the band in the hand to get the flexion/extension pattern of the arm in the spiking sequence (bending/straightening) and teach the arm/hand coming around and down, while strengthening the actions. We can also go same leg up to emphasize the pelvis and ribcage separation. A lot to it! Great for beginners/athletes that are having troubles with arm positioning in the spiking sequence. Quality over quantity! 

Let's go!

Here are 4 exercises I like for improving hip/shoulder/arm separation and technique 👊

Some of you may notice these are variations of exercises from the BFV program! 

Using exercises like the first 3 are great to build strength, improve range and get a feel for the movement. Then the last one puts you in a more dynamic situation where you have to combine all of them. But its how you do it. Its a great opportunity to implement the feeling you get in the exercise into the actual skill. This helps the skill learning process while being able to potentially use the strength from the exercise. Remember patience in each part of the sequence (hips shoulders and arm) and work on overlapping the end of the previous and the start of the next (as one ends, the other begins). 

Other important things to note is the arm in the forward swing. Don't let it drop and come forward horizontally. We need to "wrap" the ball, coming around and down. It still comes forward, but this action gets us the most out of the arm action in spiking.

Lastly, practicing the actual skill is king. So after the spiking sequence primer, we get into actual contacts (ground or airborne depending on the athlete) gradually ramping up the intensity.

I'd start low intensity and more reps for development and learning the movements, then progressing after a few weeks/months picking up the intensity in resistance and movement speed.

Let's go

Quick reminder of a way to train control and hitting different trajectories!
I talk a lot about contact points and trajectories. Remember, the ball will likely go 90 degrees to where we contact it (when hit straight on). So, if we want to hit more straight down, we gotta contact more on top of it, AND come 👉around  and down on top of it 👈
Each hit has a different way to contact it to get the desired result (hitting deeper, more down etc) and we have to adjust ourselves to get into these positions. For some of you,  this can get really confusing, so heres an easy way to work on contact points without thinking so much about angles. If we can  make it less conscious (not make athletes think so much about it), they can potentially learn it a lot easier and have it stick. Its still good to understand of course, but we don't want them to become overthinkers when playing. 
The targets give you external goals, and as you try to hit these targets, you're self organizing to get into the best position to hit it. So your body will potentially automatically adjust to hit deeper when given the external goal. Then if its slightly off, you know by how much and can try different ways to get closer and closer. So we're exploring ways to move and how it affects the ball. This is ball control! 
I'd start on the ground but make sure technique/timing has been worked on and the athlete knows the spiking sequence and to come around and down on the ball. It can be good to have this drill in the front of the mind, and if technique is off we can be switching from this drill to technique and not get much focused work done. Thats why we start and master the basics. But it can still be good to introduce for those learning the technique, and the external goal can help them figure out the movement better depending on the athlete.
Then you can set up the cones in different areas to change goals and figure out how to adjust yourself,  get on box for height, or progress to approach jumps with the hit.
A lot to it but hope this can help! 
#volleyball #volleyballtraining #volleyballplayer #vball #volleyballlife #volleyballislife #volleyballcoach #volleyballdrill #volleyballscience

Check out the difference in pull backs. More info ⬇️ 

This is dealing with separation in range and movement, not talking about TYPE of pull back (low pull/high pull). 

I think it's important to really try to look, verbalize and understand what's going on. This is also why I recommend athletes to record themselves. Often they think they're doing one thing, and try to do something to fix it, but in reality have no idea what it looks like. When they see themselves doing it they can sometimes make tbe adjustment a lot easier. Athletes with more of an athletic background may have an easier time making adjustments, but still a good idea. Then when you get the visual down you can remember the feeling. I think a lot of athletes can help their hitting mechanics by doing this. Record and really look at what you're doing at each joint action, when you're doing it, the timing of contact etc. Mirror work can help with this too.

In this video the obvious differences are the backswing and separation between the two and of course the low/straight pull vs high pull. But its less about the type of pull back and more about the rotation and separation. When I don't rotate back as much, I don't get the pre-stretch and momentum from the torso rotation and rely more on my arm for power. Some athletes just aren't actively getting enough backward rotation and separation for this. Now we need the range but also the separation in movement (moving separately) so they can overlap each other in the reverse s curve pattern. Then we can use the SSC, store elastic energy and transfer energy up the chain. The arm comes around and down as a whip to finish the sequence.

Record yourself and challenge yourself to really look at what you're doing and understand it. Its a good way to see objectively what you're doing and see how separation training and timing is improving. 

Let's get to work 📈

I see this a lot when analyzing hitters! 

Reminder that this type of hit can be from lack of separation and strength in the hips/shoulders/arms as well as just from poor coordination and wanting to use more arm to hit the ball. Usually it's someone who didn't play a variety of sports growing up or they weren't taught efficient technique.

What these athletes are doing when hitting like this is trying to push the ball to get force. Now this isn't generally an inefficient way to generate force, it depends on the situation (ie. punching, pushing etc) , but specifically for volleyball it is. In volleyball we're trying to generate a lot of force fast diagonally toward the floor. The force for the push attack is more horizontal and upward. The way we generate force and the direction it's going will determine where the ball will go if the contact is accurate. So contact point does matter but what also matters is how we get there. This will decide the tracjectory of the attack.

In order for us to get the trajectory and power we want, we need to come around and on top of the ball. This motion not only creates the angles but puts us in a good position to get force from the entire spiking sequence (puil back/reverse s curve/patient arm). Athletes not used to keeping the arm back and coming around in the last parts of the sequence will feel uncomfortable in this position but with patience and practice it will get better. Halfswing Throws are a great way to get used to being in this position as well as just overall practicing the motion without a ball and maybe with some guidance (someone tracking your arm). It's slightly different for everyone but this general motion is there. When serving/hitting deeper it is more horizontal, but even then we're still coming around from the spiking sequence. 

Hoping this video can give some of you a better visual and understanding. More on this to come.

Let's go!

Fun and engaging drill to train athlete's quickness, reaction, awareness, and speed on the court!

The Reaction Chase Drill is a great engaging way to get explosive effort. Changing up the tosses forces them to be more aware of their surroundings while reacting quick to beat their partner. Sand/uneven surfaces also has the additional benefit of the ball changing directions, training their double reactions.

The key here is allowing them the freedom to get into any ready position they want, but keeping their eyes forward at all times before the ball is tossed. In this one, once they see any part of the ball (not hear) while keeping their gaze forward, they can break to the get it. Variations can be made of course, and there are many things you can do depending on many factors, this is just one of them. We want to focus on quickness too, not physical contact to get the ball (strategy is okay). We have a good warm up prior, followed by progressions!

A great exercise for advanced athletes that we have in the Built for Volleyball online program.

Throwing can be a great way to practice spiking mechanics and train for explosiveness. BUT it depends on how you do it. The way I teach the throw is how we want the Spiking Sequence to be. So its less of a throw and more of "Spike Throw". The main differences are the Reverse S Curve pattern with the side bends, the whip coming around and down, and contact/release point. With these in mind, we train more of the pattern and the muscles the way they're used in spiking. Basically we have a lot more elbow extension (tricep) and shoulder extensors working while trying to throw far. 

I cue "far" to see how the body rearranges itself. When we're hitting the timing and contact point is very different compared to throwing straight down. 

Now this is more advanced and some of you may not need this just yet. You may need some general strengthening, mobility and technique work (spiking sequence) before adding resistance to it. But when you are ready, remembering the technique is key. It helps to visualize a net and hitting far and down. We also don't need a lot of weight. In volleyball we're not carrying extra weight (like in baseball for example) so we're only dealing with bodyweight and about 10oz on contact. We can also start off slow and then pick up intensity in speed. This is meant to improve the stretch reflex and add load to the eccentric actions in the spiking sequence of the arm and some resistance in its concentric (think weighted plyos for the arm), and we don't need a lot! 100-250 g can be good for a lot of you. Some may handle more but this isnt a 1rm max or more is better. We want optimal. Just what you need.

I'd keep the reps low and quality high. Technique and ramping up explosiveness when comfortable. Again, there are prerequisite exercises for this! 

Lets get to work 📈

You have more control than you think! 

Ball control is manipulation. You can do different actions to manipulate the ball. When you master these different actions and figure out what they do, you can be better prepared to use them when you need it. 

I also like this for athletes going from indoor to the beach and adjusting/improving their awareness. It can feel weird looking up and seeing the sky when you've been inside and tracking the ball. There's a lot more to it and every athlete is different!

One of the keys for shoulder health for hitting is being able to move the shoulder blade optimally within the movement.

Training the serratus to rotate our shoulder blade up (upward rotate, think reach up) and forward (protraction) allows us to get into optimal positions for hitting. If we're not able to get into these positions properly, we can start compensating, doing any other movements we can in attempt to get into the position but not having the muscles and their coordination trained to do so. Some athletes are in an excessive "down and back" pattern with their shoulders, when in hitting, we need to get our shoulder blade to move up and forward. Doing an exercise like this can help! 

It also works with others to stabilize the whole shoulder joint complex throughout the movement. This is key for shoulder health. We're moving so fast in these positions, not only do we need to get into these positions,  but be able to have the muscles that stabilize the shoulder work together well. There are other progressions/exercises to help build the movement and tissue, as well as work other important shoulder/scapula areas needed for healthy shoulders. And we need to adapt to higher speeds as well.

If you've never trained this before I'd spend some time building the mind muscle connection and gaining movement in the scapula in these patterns. Really work to develop this muscle and movement. For some it may take weeks/months. Then, when practicing hitting, it can be good to take your time and starting at a low intensity learning how to apply this new movement pattern of upwardly rotating. Of course there are other important factors involved with the shoulder, but this is one of the keys. A lot to it but hope this helps! Take your time! 

Lets go

The float doesn't have to be an "easier" serve. If you serve lightly then it is, but floats can do a nasty dance if done with the intent to drive the ball.

Remember a drill is about how we do something and what the intent is behind it. Anyone can just serve but the WAY we do it and what we're focusing on is key. In this drill all we're focusing on is the contact accuracy and DRIVING through the ball. This contact point is dead center on the ball with the meat of your palm. Hand is relaxed but stiff enough to resist the ball on contact. 

When driving through the ball you're basically not stopping your arm until after contact is made. Throughout the contact you're continuously trying to swing through the ball and toward your target. This gives more force to the ball and more of a linear path if contact point is good. When practicing serving more linear against the wall, you want to make sure the path is at a height that can go over the net, so mark off your net height on the wall and aim for within 1-2 feet over that.

Keep in mind we might not always just want to hit it as hard as we can for a float, and you can stop your hand on contact during a float too - but this gives it pace. We need to develop a "touch" to find the right amount and this "drive" can give the ball more pace and direction to your current float. If technique is the issue I recommend making sure you have a strong technical foundation using the spiking sequence well, and developing an accurate contact. I have a lot of content on this so check it out!

Let's go

In the first phases of BFV, one of the keys we prioritize is movement patterns/quality. This goes for the Spiking Sequence, Spike Approach and court movements as well. 

A lot of the times athletes struggle to move well on the court because of poor movement patterns and lack the ability to get into those positions. This is a drill that takes the time to isolate some of the movements we'll see on the court and that can help us get into better positions to pass/dig the ball. One of the main things athletes struggle with in this drill is the knee drop. They hesitate or lean back to carefully get into the position and it just looks/feels awkward. Sometimes even just spending more time in this position can help, but we also need to be able to move INTO this position. We start slowly and then can pick it up as it gets easier. If you're not used to being in this position, chances are slim the body will go here in games/practices. The backward diagonal is good to be able to track the ball well across the court. Athletes are good at going side-to-side, but once they see it's further back or shorter, they don't have these movements done to be able to adjust quickly. So they get caught high. Just like the knee drop, the more we do these movements, the more automatic it will become (when paired with proper cue training). This is more for the movements and establishing good movement patterns. Each work on the different angles/directions it can be used, and it's also a good idea to have general movements incorporated into the training as well to widen the movement bank that can help with movement patterns on the volleyball court. 

There's a lot more to it but hope this helps. Practice the movement and it'll become more comfortable, automatic and fast. Questions in the comments!

Let's get to work! 📈

One of the strength and technique exercises that improved my spiking!

I made this exercise when I was struggling with my technique and overall spiking power. I wanted to learn how to just use my torso to rotate in the reverse s curve I was discovering back then as well. To do that I decided to take out the arms and resist this pattern. 

This exercise can use bands or cables and pulls you down and back like how we'd be in the pull back. We then rotate the torso forward with the side bend, coming up slightly, and this forward/upward movement is resisted. I've now found other ways to resist it while working on the technique even better, but it's still a great exercise and it's in the BFV program.

Athletes that are more arm dominant or want to learn the pattern can use this to learn what it feels like to actually use the torso rotators in the reverse s curve pattern and strengthen them! I recommend a base of h/s separation and strength, but what you need and how you program it will depend! Practicing the technique prior and alongside exercises like half swing sequence and gradually putting it together with spiking practice (grounded and eventually airborne) is a great idea. A lot more to it but hope this helps.

Go get it

Tag someone who needs these 👀 📈 can be done anywhere

If you have a volleyball that would be ideal, but if not you can always go to the half swing sequence/resisted variation. The approach jump throws are the variation in my previous post to practice the approach and spiking sequence in the air. Ball doesn't need to be weighted and intensity in the throw doesn't need to be high! 

The half swing sequence is something I'd recommend for those learning the technique or want to maintain the pattern when away from the gym. It can be done resisted and/or at a faster rate like in the actual spike. But of course, we gotta get the actually skill in if we can. In BFV we build the technique with drills like these and progress into drills that incorporate more airborne mechanics and timing (with a set/over a net etc). We gotta have that base before progressing and take one step at a time.

These are for quality over quantity, and I always encourage reflecting on these drills even after the fact, and not just relying on the reps and sets. Of course, we don't want to overdo it (especially with the jumps and hits) but practice the movement, gradually increase the intensity, and learn and remember the feel for the movement. I'd go for 10 reps of 2-3 reps for the half swings, and gradually working into a maximal spike with emphasis on technique for the spikes 2-5 reps (can do per side too) and about 2- reps of the approach jump throws. Lots of rest in between. Train the pattern fresh for these, depending on the athlete/level etc. A lot more to it but hope this helps!

Let's get to work!

#volleyball #volleyballtraining #volleyballlife #volleyballplayer #vball #vballplayer #volleyballdrills #volleyballcoach #volleyballscience

Keep the hands and fingers strong for volleyball and life!

I've had a couple of injuries around the hand and while they seem small, it can affect your game play. If you keep going without proper rehab, it just gets worse. 

Strengthening the entire lower arm generally and specific to volleyball is a good way to build resiliency and help reduce the likelihood of injuries. Using rings like these are great to work the tiny muscles in the fingers that are often neglected. The finger plank progression we have in BFV is also a great way to build strength in the hands/fingers in the hand pass/blocking position. Pronation is part of the spiking sequence and wrist flexion can be used in different directions to manipulate the ball. We also need to gradually build our resiliency through actual playing and doing the actions as well (volleying, rapid volleys, blocking, hitting etc)

But generally speaking it's just a good idea to make sure the entire lower arm is ready and strong in all of its actions, for sport/activity and life as well. This doesn't mean we need to dedicate hours a day on it, but if you can sneak something like this at in at the end of your workouts 2-3 times a week and work to maintain it, that can go a long way. A lot to it!

Some athletes try to "open up" more but don't actually work through the spiking sequence!

If you're opening up like in the first demonstration, you can get more momentum into the ball, which is still better than nothing. But if we want to optimize our spiking technique and spike better and harder, it's best to learn, practice, and master the spiking sequence.

When we use the sequence well, we are opening up, but we're actually getting separation between the two parts (rib cage and pelvis). This separation allows us to use the SSC in the torso rotators, as opposed to just twisting the body as one part. All of the movements in the sequence overlap each other and accumulate force and transfer it up the chain into the arm. So like in my posts about having a patient arm, the torso needs to be patient as well. So that when the hips shift forward, they stay back and then come forward as the hips are ending their movement. 

This can be practiced just by doing the movement without the ball slowly! The half-swing sequence we use in BFV (in my feed too) is a great way to get a feel for the movement and practice separating each of them. We take our time engraining this pattern! Then we take this and go into the halfswing throws and apply it to the actual spike! If this is new to you, you're going to need a lot of reps! So patience and consistency are key.

One of the keys for being a great hitter! 

Being able to hit in less than optimal positions is a great skill for hitters to master. Or, being able to adjust and get in an optimal position in less than optimal situations.

This is a drill where we focus on developing the skill of hitting off a short approach. We focus first on the technique and timing, then we can vary the sets and speed up/slow down the play. The athlete then has to adjust and shorten and start their approach earlier or delay. So you can work from a no approach hit to a 2-3 step approach. The idea is to develop this skill and put yourself in a good position (timing and contact point) to get a good hit and score in faster transition plays/out of system plays.

From here you can work on hitting better shots doing the 3 point contact drill (putting targets up to hit in various positions). I like harder deeper hits mixing it with hits more down. Having these in your bag are key! As you get better and hitting these you can focus on hitting them harder as well.

Trouble hand passing? Here are some tips.

The best passers are able to track the ball and strike it well. This takes a lot of practice. If you're not an athlete who grew up playing sports, tracking will be weird to you. But over time, you develop an awareness that helps you anticipate where the ball will land. When you pair that with good movement training and practice, you can teach yourself the actions that are paired with those cues (cues being what you see in the trajectory of the ball, and anything before).

The next tip seems obvious, but you'd be surprised how many athletes miss their sweet spot on their hands. Just like platform accuracy for forearm passing, hand passing needs accurate contacts as well. Some can get away with it, but if we want to be consistent, learning to contact in the optimal position will help. This drill can help with hand positioning and accurate contacts. 

Now there's a lot more to it of course, but the better we can get at these 2 things, the better your hand passing will be. We gotta track to put ourselves in a better position to pass. The bonus tip gives some extra advice on positioning and preparing to hand pass, and getting more energy into the ball!

Great drill to build the spring in the lower leg and prep for more intense plyometrics.

Lower level plyometric exercises like this is a great way to introduce and accumulate quick-swtich reps, focusing on light and quick contacts. This is building the resliency of the tissues around the lower leg and getting it used to faster contraction speeds and "elasticity". For a lot of athletes getting back into it or starting out, they need to accumulate these reps overtime to build up to more intense and explosive contractions and movements. The body isn't used to fast contacts like this, so it's a good idea for it to be gradually introduced and progressed in intensity.

In this drill we're also getting multiple contact angles and challenging the muscles around the feet and lower leg to contract quickly to stop and reverse out of it in different directions. This is great for overall lower leg development and preparing us for explosive movements in different positions. 

We can start double leg and increase the intensity with speed/distance/height, and switch to single leg with a similar progression as soon as you're ready and not experiencing any negative effects from the load on the body (shin splints, pain around the feet ankle etc). 

A lot to it but hope this helps! Remember, the body will adapt to a lot if you progress well, give it enough time and are consistent. With the right training you can be a lot more bouncy and explosive on the court.

A good example from @kianayache of the spiking sequence.

All of the parts overlap the previous to transfer the energy to the next part. For example, as the hips are ending, the torso rotation begins. These movements are fluid and powerful!

Keep in mind this is a simplified version. Within each part, there are many things going on that make the movement effective. There's a lot going on here with different muscles working etc. But a big key is "patience" in each movement! This allows each part to use the stretch shortening cycle and pass on the energy up the chain and eventually go through the ball. 

The sequence takes time to build, and it looks slightly different for everyone. But you can learn these checkpoints and optimize them for yourself to improve your hitting.

Great drill to help athletes struggling with their timing!

When starting out with this drill, I like to keep the tosses consistent to allow the athlete to work on their timing with their spike approach technique. If they're new to this, it can be weird combining the two actions (explosive spike approach jump timed with a ball). A lot of athletes struggle with approach jumping without the ball vs with the ball, and this is a great way to engrain the pattern while developing the timing. 

From there athletes can mix up the tosses to put the approacher in different situations where they have to ADJUST their approach and get back to the optimal hitting position (highest point in their jump, reach and contact point slightly in front of them - depending on what they want to do with the ball). So if they go into too early, they need to be able to adjust their approach by slowing down so they can approach explosively into the ball and reach it at it's highest point - as opposed to jumping backwards. Tossers can toss from different positions and even speed it up.

This drill allows us to work on identifying the set made and engrain the skills/actions for different sets. The better we get at these skills, the more automatic and faster they will be. It's also great in exposing what the athlete is currently doing. Great for beginners or athletes wanting to sharpen their blades. 2-4 sets of 2 quality jumps or for 10 minutes with enough rest in between jumps (ie. having a line up if done with a team). A lot to it but hope this helps! Pieces to the puzzle.

Here are 3 single leg exercises!

Single leg exercises are great to do for many reasons like exposing and training any imbalances and developing strength/explosiveness in each leg. Some athletes are so used to double leg actions and lack abilities like loading one leg, stabliizing, planting and exploding quickly in a cut etc.

Keep in mind that what YOU need will depend on a lot of factors. Single leg exercises can be regressed so that almost anyone can do them. We can use assistance to reduce our bodyweight but still get load at the level we need to build gradually. Some athletes make the mistake of starting off too intense and get injuries. Ways to assist can be with bands, chairs or holding yourself up with the side bars on the rack, pool, surface progressions etc. 

We could also start double leg and gradually work our way to single leg progressions. Progressions with/without shoes can also be done, microdosing barefoot low level plyometric contacts (depending on the athlete). 

Here I'm doing lower level plyometrics in terms of effort in the jump, but I'm focusing on quick switches/reversals out of the bottom. This is developing the stretch-shortening cycle at a low level and preparing us for more advanced plyometrics, and overall is a good way to develop the quick switch. We can start at slower "switches" or longer ground contact times, or reduce the bodyweight/impact with assistance, pool or surface progressions (grass etc). From there we can pick up the intensity in switches, reduce the amount of reps and add some speed/load into the bottom with light weights/bands. DB RFESS is a great way to develop the strength in each leg and can be varied by foot placement/depth and effort to change the emphasis!

Sets and reps can vary depending on the phase/emphasis! Its a good idea to start lower intensity. Lower intensity work can be longer and timed quality reps, while higher intensity can be shorter duration/reps and more explosive, quality reps with more rest in between.

2 variations of explosive plyometric exercises! 

For both of these the intent is to get through the range of motion as fast and as explosive as possible, the basic differences are the knee angles and ground contact times.

With these 2 variations we're training the "fast" stretch shortening cycle and the "slow" stretch shortening cycle. There are many reasons why training both are beneficial like being able to stop rapidly and change directions in short times (vertically or horizontally - which can be trained with other exercises as well). Many times in volleyball we need to get up for the block or an attack rapidly and we can't always sink lower before. Other times we have situations like spike approach jumps with deeper knee bends (90 or just above parallel) or we have to change directions from a deeper knee angle in a plant/cut. There are also differences depending on the surface (indoor vs beach) and differences in each leg in the approach jump. So we're training the ability to be explosive out of both types of stretch-shortening cycle speeds.

Of course these are more advanced exercises and beginners would benefit more from lower level plyometrics/foundational exercises to build, and the way it would be programmed into your training can be different for everyone. Sets and reps can vary between 2-5+ sets of 3-5 reps. Shorter, intensive reps with longer breaks in between reps.

Here's a simple way to improve your hitting training and overall hits 🏐

If the toss is inconsistent, it can change our pattern and timing and take our focus away from the movement. So mastering the toss is a great way to help you get more consistent tosses and be able to focus on the same pattern and timing. 

For some athletes struggling with the control I get them to do 3-5 consistent tosses WITH the pull back to engrain the pattern. Then on the next one they can hit.

Now of course, unless its being held in the same spot, its not always going to be the same. The idea is to set your self up for better opportunities for training the sequence and contacting in the goal position. Depending on the athlete, we also want to make sure that technique work WITHOUT the ball has been done as well. 

Then, we can also use the different tosses to learn how to adjust and get back into the goal position for a good pull back and optimal power (instead of leaning over and contacting the ball, adjust). This can give us a better sense of adjusting ourselves to contact the ball well, and carry that over to when we're approaching toward an actual set. So now instead of jumping backwards, you're able to identify the set, and position yourself or time it better to get to the goal position (with practice of course). 

So the toss can be great for getting consistent spiking and serving reps, ensuring you're setting your self up for a good use of the approach and spiking sequence (tossing in front and positioning yourself so the ball is slightly more toward your hitting side and at a good contact point) and practicing being able to adjust! Pieces to the puzzle 🧩

Quick tip for athletes that are having troubles generating power in their hit.

The spiking sequence is composed of overlapping actions that transfer energy to the next. If we don’t set ourselves up well we won't be able to use the actions well. 

The torso rotation is a huge component to power in the spiking sequence. Not getting a good pull back limits your ability to use the torso rotation to generate force and transfer it to the arm.

Keep in mind its best to practice this on the ground and engrain the pattern and remember the feeling and then from there you can gradually work into airborne drills to get used to using it in the air. But ground work is great to make the skill more automatic. We also don't need a ton of range, 90 degrees may be the upper limit, we want to be able to use our range optimally to generate force. A lot of you might have the range but just have troubles using it in the sequence. This is where technique drills like the half swing sequence work well and practicing on the ground etc. The pull back row and backward twists are great exercises to develop a better pull back (while practicing the pattern) and the reverse trunk twist to start developing better hip and torso separation! 

A lot to it and hope this helps. Let's get to work 📈

Exercise for the spike and block approach! 

The bands resists the approach with the emphasis to drive and push explosively in the penultimate (2nd to last) step. It can also help teach us to drive more down to get the hips lower and set the depth for the approach jump.I have a bit of a step into it making it more of a 3 step as opposed to a 2 in the video, but you can keep the feet parallel, start with a lean and focus on just pushing off the left or right leg to go into the 2 step approach.

The band resisted block approach is great to help train pushing off laterally (away from midline) with the outside/opposite leg to go the direction you want. If you want to go right, we need to push off explosively with the left. And what you need can depend! Some athletes can benefit from just doing a hip shift/lateral lunge to teach the abduction of the hip (bringing the leg out) to drive the hips laterally. You'll feel this in the side of the glute if doing this well! So this teaches the movement pattern and develops strength in the pattern to move better in the block. Then following through with the block approach to improve explosiveness in it. 

Sets and reps can range from 2-4 sets of 2-4 LR! 

These are just some of the ways we can improve performance in the approach and are in BFV. If you haven't signed up yet hit the link in my bio to start training to improve your hitting power, vertical and overall volleyball performance.

This is a really simple drill to help athletes hit different trajectories without thinking so much about contact points!

The idea is having an external goal to aim at which in turn changes your body position. The body self-organizes. For example, if we want to throw a ball to the sky, without thinking so much about it you're going to angle your body so you can get a better trajectory. If you wanted to throw straight down, you're likely going to release the ball at a point where the ball will go straight down. If the ball is a little bit off, now you know by how much because of the visual target/goal. 

The reason why this is important is because if we can coach an athlete without using too many words, learning is going to be a lot easier. The body adjusts based off the feedback. Then if the athlete needs more direction, we can give more bit by bit.

The other reason is because trajectory is all about contact points, manipulation and how we get there. We can train and become a lot better at controlling the ball with this basic drill and progress from there. The deepest target is important because as we advance in level, hitting deep and harder is one of the keys to hitting success. As we get better at this, we learn how to adjust our approach and jump to contact the point at different areas to change the trajectory of the ball. We can also change the target area and where we are facing to get work on different hitting angles. 

Of course there are other ways to manipulate the ball with different arm/wrist actions and contact points, but this is a great addition to introductory exercises! Keep in mind that the way we GET to the contact point also matters for trajectory as well (the whole spiking sequence and direction before contacting the ball), so that doesn't mean just because you contact it at a certain point that it's going to go more or less 90 degrees. So while this can help us self-organize, I'd also like to see good control and self-regulation of the Spiking Sequence before getting into drills like this.

Tag someone who this can help!

The Spiking Sequence is a series of actions overlapping the next. Each action needs to be used well to better produce force and transfer it into the ball. The pull back is one of the actions that uses the stretch shortening cycle (we stretch and shorten the muscles). If we don't have enough range/separation, we don't get the pre-stretch to power the shortening/forward action.

Keep in mind we just enough separation at the right time to get a rapid stretch. The best hitters have at most a 90 degree backward rotation within the sequence, but this can vary depending on the situation. Most athletes that can benefit from more separation and technique training are the ones that visibly don't have the separation in the hips and torso just before the forward action of the swing (record!). 

A lot to it and everyone's situation is different but hope this helps!

Some tips for hitters struggling with this!

One of the keys here is repetition. The body will develop a strong pathway of movement with the movements you do most often. It will become automatic. Even if the set is inconsistent, we can still train our ability to identify sets better and improve our responses to these sets. When you practice the movement more, it improves your ability to see when that move is available/optimal to do. If you've never done it before, you don't have that experience yet.

Practicing just the adjustment approach without the ball can be a great place to start, just focusing on the pattern so it's more comfortable when you get into the Approach Catches. 

A lot of athletes will do this once but then never do it again. But the consistency and accumulation of reps overtime will develop the pattern a lot better, improve your ability to adjust, and put yourself in a better position to hit more often. These are just 2 ways to help but a lot to it!

Another visual of the patient arm and coming around and down! 

The spiking sequence has 5 main parts and each are separated in movement and range. The arm action is separated from the torso so as the torso rotates forward, the arm stays back and loaded. 

What I'm also showing slightly here is the difference between coming around and down on the ball and doing more of a push swing, having a horizontal trajectory. I'm okay sometimes with having different arm swings, but when it comes to using the sequence optimally to get power efficiently, its a good idea to come around and down. Even if we want to have a more horizontal trajectory, we can still come around and down, just slightly less down than other hits (think deeper hits and serves vs more down). This way we're able to transfer the energy from the first parts of the sequence and use the contractions in our arm well, and have an optimal direction of force to get the ball over the net and down. 

A lot to it but hope it helps! 👊

Quick tip for getting topspin on the ball! 

If we can't contact the ball accurately, it's going to be harder to get the trajectory and spin we want. And if we want the ball to go more down, it's a good idea to adjust the contact point to do so. We can technically get topspin even if we're under the ball, but the way we usually want to hit it is forward and down. These are just a couple of tips for getting topspin if you want. And we don't necessarily have to "flick the wrist," we'd just have to alter our contact points, and come around and down with the elbow-whip to get the direction we want. But the wrist can help finish the whip and wrap the ball, depending on what you want to do with the ball. We can use it to manipulate the ball in different ways, which is great to have in your bag as a hitter.  I'm a fan of intentional hybrid hits and curves too, all requiring different types of contacts and manipulation.

3 drills to do for your warm up! 

It may seem simple but remember, it's HOW you do it and what the focus is that makes a difference.

In the warm up is a great time to accumulate reps and build/reinforce your technique. So it can be good for warm-up and skill work.

I always start with forearm passes and volleys and gradually progressing the drills (focus/complexity etc). When doing the passes we can focus on the platform mechanics, tracking the ball (trajectory and movement patterns), body positioning (ready position and old man), contact accuracy and more. All of these accumulate over time and build the pattern. For example I can practice my passing footwork and staying in my ready position/old man and do this over and over.

The volleys we can focus again on tracking with the forehead, body positioning (loaded), and accurate contacts with the hands and more. You can take out the low volley and just go repeat with your partner/against a wall. Again, focusing on the skill you're trying to build and being consistent. You can also get creative with both of these and work different angles, passing shorter balls, higher balls ans adjusting etc.

1 arm repeats are a fun way to accumulate these "random reps" and build a better touch and manipulation through exposure and time. What's important here again is the focus on the skill and putting yourself in a good position to get the ball up and toward your partner. Sometimes athletes just contact it without the intention to direct it anywhere. When they get the hang of it they can learn to manipulate the ball better! I encourage all athletes to do these and change up/challenge yourselves with different goals/tempos like speeding it up or trying to "beat" your partner.

You can go until what you're working on is more consistent if "touching up" but if you're pressed for time or its just for accumulation you can keep it to 10-20 each and 5 min 1 arm repeats. I do both. These are just some ways to build! Pieces to the puzzle.

This contrast is in phase 5 of the Built For Volleyball program!

Love using the bands because of the increase in tension as the bands lengthen. Throughout the jump we need to power through triple extension and the bands are a great way to resist it when programmed and done well. The bands also increase the speed into the bottom which means we have to generate more force quickly to stop ourselves quickly reverse out of it and jump. So we're overloading the eccentric-isometric switch at the bottom as well. 

Then we want to rest and do unloaded or assisted jumps! This is a great addition to an explosive exercise when done well. 

We can alter the knee angle to change the emphasis to fast/slow stretch shortening cycle if the athlete is ready. I'm working the slower portion (still explosive, not a slow movement, more ground contact time/time to stretch and shorten) which we do get into in volleyball.

Keep in mind this is Phase 5! So there are requisite stages before hitting these. Reps are low and intensity and rest are high! We want to be explosive and reactive.

Going over the Spiking Sequence with athletes at the clinic!

Each part of the sequence is separated in range and movement, overlapping the previous. This creates a stretch in the muscles that we can use to get a powerful contraction in the spike. I have a lot of information on this throughout my feed!

One of the common mistakes when getting power and hitting optimally is not getting into the good positions with the reverse s curve. This is clearly seen when the arm comes sideways or the elbow leads. The reverse s curve is backward-forward-circular rotation, meaning we rotate back and come around and down on the ball (torso and arm). Getting into these positions allow us to better use the rotation from the torso and transfer the energy to the arm for a better, powerful whip, while creating a good trajectory of the ball (coming around and down on the ball). Not only that but each action needs to overlap the previous for the energy to transfer.

Of course, different situations can call for variations in the arm action, but this is the base for optimal hitting. There are checkpoints we can look out for. It looks different for everyone, but it's there.

A reminder of one of the ways to get a more accurate contact for those consistently hitting their wrists 🏐 

The cool thing about the body is that it will adapt to something if you give it enough time and reps. If you're an athlete that would always contact their wrist or somewhere else and didn't do anything about it, chances are your body adapted to this and is now the primary way you hit. Meaning no matter what you do it will try to get back to this position because thats all it knows. Its a habit. 

The good news is we can change it by giving you a new goal and building a new pattern. Just like all skills this takes patience! Try letting go of the frustration and trusting the process. 

Getting into the new goal position and feeling what its like can cause some shifts in your movement. If your body doesnt know what its like to be in that position, its less likely to go there or trust it consistently. So we need to introduce it. Start by literally looking at the ball and seeing where you want to contact the ball. Then notice the way your body is positioned and how it feels to be in it. The goal position can vary.

Then we need to practice the pattern. In this drill some athletes will notice their arm wants to go somewhere else and this is part of their reason for inaccurate hits. Others may find they actually lose concentration, think about something else or literally look somewhere else. Practice discipline, focus, and vision here. Have a partner hold it so you can move better.

Then we gotta actually work on the skill. This isn't maximal, we need to just get used to combining the actions with the timing. This is where you can bring all the focus, visualization and feeling in. If you can make >95% accurate contacts, you can increase the intensity by 10-25%. 

Super basic but sometimes thats what you need. Be willing to go back, dial in and focus on what you need to get better and the results will show.

Here are 2 exercises from the Built For Volleyball program that can be used as a warm up!

The focus here is getting active separation from the hips and shoulders (pelvis and ribcage). I've talked a lot about the importance of this separation within the Spiking Sequence to use the muscles that rotate the torso optimally. 

Some athletes might have the range but not the strength or the coordination. The Reverse Trunk Twist is a basic exercise that can help improve the range and strength. The rhythm twist is a great way to learn how and develop the ability to quickly switch and contract when the oblqiues are stretched.

This is focused primarily on the torso portion of the Spiking Sequence, so keep in mind there are other things we can do to prepare the rest of the body, and other ways we can warm up this type of separation. This is just a couple options. But this is a great addition to a warm up for those that are lacking the separation and want to make sure they're getting enough and preparing it well. It's also a good idea to then warm up the actual skill after these and apply the separation to the pattern. Sets and reps can be any where from 1-2 sets of 5-10 both sides depending on the athlete and situation. The rhythm twists I like going by feel and gradually building up and then snapping back and forth when ready. This is usually about 10-15 LR low intensity.

A lot to it but hope this helps!

Great drill for ball control/warm up!

This drill involves a lot. We're improving our ability to manipulate the ball. Athletes that have a hard time with this will be running all over the place, but in time with the right training paired, they will be able to control the ball and their movements/positioning a lot better.

I encourage athletes to experiment with ways to contact the ball and try to make it "easier" for yourself and figure out what happens to the ball when you contact it a certain way. Higher is a good option to give yourself more time. Sometimes contacts don't have intention, so this is a good way to be more deliberate with where you want to put the ball (if you give yourself a "bad dig" its going to be harder to set and if you give your self a bad set, its going to be harder to hit). 

Another key is anticipation and communication. As you're doing this, you may find your partner struggling, or they change positions. This is a great time to practice anticipating what will happen and how you can help (instead of just standing there), and communicate what you're doing. These skills are extremely valuable and can be worked on in almost all drills and in life as well. 

For some athletes just doing the dig to self to a catch (instead of a set)  is a great place to start. A lot to it but hope it helps!

Mastering the spiking sequence will take a long time, and it's different for everyone. So it depends!

Regardless, it's more about the reps within that time. The best thing you can do is try to repeat the same pattern over and over and make the grooves deep. The more we do this, the more likely we will master the skill and make it automatic. We need quality REPS.

This doesn't have to be intense right away. In the Built for Volleyball program, we start off with engraining the pattern on the ground at a low intensity with and without the ball. The point is not to hit hard right away but to groove the patterns. The goal is to establish this in the beginning and carry it with you throughout training and practices, etc. You're creating the blueprint for your system to run automatically.

I love visualization for this as well, paired with some movement. This way, we're training the pattern but without the actual intensity. 

Keep in mind that it will be a long process, and while working to master it, there will be moments of greatness and moments when you may not see results as clearly. But if you do your best to trust it and continue to groove the patterns, you'll be closer to making it more automatic. Depending on the athlete/situation you can create variability during or after it's more automatic.

A lot of coaches/players cringe at one arm attempts and some say it's a bad habit. Sometimes the problem is not using one arm, but not being good at it. When athletes don't get behind the ball enough or track it poorly, then the ball shanks. This is not a bad habit when done well and on purpose. 

Sometimes we don't have enough time to get both arms behind the ball. A 1 arm platform is a great option. This is a skill and can be improved with practice to develop the tracking, coordination and identifying when to use it quickly. If there's nothing being learned athletes will keep doing the same thing over and over as long as it serves them some purpose. When they learn how to use their arms in a way to create a platform to get the ball up (and get a lot of reps with it) the body puts this into a system of actions that it can pull from. The better it's develped the faster it's pulled. Something you can think of is trying to track the ball with your elbows, trying to get them behind the ball. This will bring your platform more behind to stop the ball from going passed you. This also applies to 2 arm platforms. Now it fully depends on where it hits you, how you move and the tracjectory of the ball. You could have your arm flat like in the first clip and have it contact perfectly and stay behind it. You could also track with the elbows but not be accurate and still shank the ball. We need tracking to be improved as well.

Having someone toss you balls or throwing it against a wall is a good way to just practice the movement, tracking and "touch" to manipulate the ball better. Even 1 arm touches just keeping the ball up is a great place to start! You can work on keeping an "open platform" (arms apart) to be able to move your arms separately better/faster. For a lot of athletes it will be a lot of re-wiring, especially the coordination and identifying when to use it. This will take time. So start small and build off of it with different speeds and situations. A lot to it.

Here's a drill to help train hitting sharp cross!

When you only have a ball and a wall, this is a good way to work on hitting angles while still hitting toward the wall. We're imagining the line is the net, and if you want to work on sharp cross then ideally the line is 90 degrees to the wall you're hitting at. Then you position yourself so you face cross court in relation to this line, toss, and try to hit over the line toward the wall. We can work other angles as well, just by practicing the positioning and spiking motion to contact the ball in a way that makes it hit the wall. 

If you don't have a line you can set up a piece of tape to act as the net. And it's a good idea to have a strong technical foundation before getting to something like this. If you have access to a net and multiple balls then you can work on it by standing on a box that's ideally your jump height and hitting off a self-toss, over and over. The point is to work on the skill without being in the air to start. Of course, it does take time and you'll still need to practice it in the air, but this will help it become more automatic when hitting airborne. Also keep in mind that you should mark out 9 meters in width (simulating the width of the court) to give you a reference if your hits are in or out. Standing hits will be different, and this line=net isn't perfect, I could be more back to not hit "the net", but it's still good to have a reference and way to practice if you don't have a net.

Pieces to the puzzle! Hope this helps.

Here's a simple way to work on digging skills!

Training a new skill takes a lot of repetitions to develop the pattern well. The more reps we get doing one thing the more automatic it will become. You've grooved the pathways for fast responses. It's also great for developing the touch to manipulate the ball better.

Sometimes athletes just aren't getting enough quality reps to engrain the pattern. This is at a beginner level, but when you're learning a new skill, you want to give it the time it needs to build the pathways. You can even practice without the ball (shadow passing, digging etc). If you have a partner to toss/hit at you that would be ideal, starting lightly and building from there. Then you can progress in speed, moving to position, identifying better in different situations etc. But if you don't, a wall will do. You'll just need to make sure you're in the ready position you want to be in after the toss.

I recommend working only on 1-2 skills (basic forearm and overhead digs) and then getting really good at those as a foundation, then building off that in different overhead digs, one arm digs etc emphasizing the movement pattern from a ready position and identifying when to use them. Freestyle 1 arm contacts are great as well on a wall or with a partner, as well as intentional pepper variations.

2 drills you can do at home to improve your spiking!

First one up is the Wall Separation Drill. Made a post on this a couple of days ago going deeper into it. We're training to improve the separation in RANGE between the torso and the hips in the backward rotation portion of the Spiking Sequence. The next part of the drill is working the separation in MOVEMENT, the ability to move the different parts independently (ie. torso). This allows us to generate force at each part and overlap the previous to transfer it up the chain and eventually into the ball. The better we're able to move these separately and time it, the better the transfer of energy, the better the hit (when accurately contacted). The wall serves as a guide for the amount you're able to rotate back and a way to keep you honest in your technique (not hitting the wall).

Second is the Wall Pull Back Drill, similar but focuses more on the backward rotation/pull back action. This is a good exercise if you want to engrain a new Pull Back pattern, being in a position you'd be in in the air but isolating the pull back. Keeping the opposite arm up and pushed against the wall also gives you a reference to keep you honest and see how much you're actually separating within the sequence. If you can get your hitting shoulder aligned with the opposite arm, then this is good separation. I get a lot of questions about the opposite arm as well and this can help you train the overall pattern with enough reps. If you have more of a low pull you start with the hitting arm lower on the wall vs pulling back from higher. You can add in the Hip Shift gradually just after the Pull Back is complete, and then speed it up as well to work on the pattern so that as the Pull Back ends you're starting the Hip Shift

Keep in mind its a good idea to practice these patterns gradually in an actual spike, on the ground and working your way up to the air with airborne drills as well. A lot to it! Hope this helps those without equipment/wanting to improve their spiking technique! Online program available!!

Here's a simple drill that can help improve pancakes!

This is a great skill to have in the bag to still get underneath the ball. Some coaches might not like pancakes because their athletes don't get them up well. While there may be a better option in many scenarios, it's usually because the athlete just isn't good at them. If they're not good at the skill, the result won't be good. When they practice the skill, they're able to identify when it's a good time to use it and track it better to get a more accurate contact. It's also good to learn how to fall efficiently from different positions (and get back up), and practicing the motions gradually and progressively is key. If they don't have the foundational skills of falling, defense is going to be tough in general.

This is not saying that all tips should be picked up by a pancake, but it's worth having the option. We should still be able to move to the ball and try to scoop it up, and adjust mid-tracking to put yourself in a better position to get the ball up, which should still be practiced as well. If they're just dropping and falling straight down for every ball and still not getting it because they're not actually moving toward the ball, this can be a bad habit. But movement and responses are skills and can be practiced and engrained.

This is a drill to just work on the falling motion, tracking and contact accuracy of the pancake. You can practice falling from different positions as well, but this is the first level to isolate the mechanics while working on other aspects on the side like movement, ball control and falling from standing positions etc. You can progress by moving back to add speed, from a defensive position, partner tossing situation specific etc

A lot to it but hope this helps! Let's keep putting in the work

Drill for quickness on defense! 

On defense we need to be stopped and ready. Sometimes there are deviations in the hit (off the block) or you miss-track the ball. We need to be able to adjust and reposition ourselves. This move here is a repositioning/"hidden" step that puts us in a position to be explosive in the direction we want to go. After a split step or stopping, we swivel the hips to push off the outside leg in the direction we want to go. Our eyes are on the ball but our hips might be facing another way. This is another way hip and shoulder separation is important in volleyball and athletic movement.

Keep in mind what you do can change depending on the situation, this is just one of the good movements to have in your bank. So it's a good idea to practice straight regular/reactive/specific cue reactive sprints in side, forward and backward directions, curvilinear paths, as well as sharper changes in direction while chasing. You can also practice tracking an actual ball and train double reactions and commiting to getting the ball up. The better we get at it, the faster the tracking and switch will be. Ensuring you're also prepared/training to be better at falling and getting back up is also key. Sets and reps can range from 2-6 of 1 short sprint (2-10+ meters) with a lot of rest. Practicing the movement first (twist/turn and push) is a good idea and working your way up in intensity and the progressions/variations.A lot to it! Hope this helps.

Quick tip for passers! 

I talk a lot about tracking the ball to get behind and under in the direciton we want the ball to go. The sweet spot is the place I call that we actually want the ball to contact. So when we're tracking the ball, we're tracking it so that it lands here. From here you're able to manipulate the ball much better with angles and taking off/adding energy.

This is Platform Accuracy. Sometimes athletes have the right angles, but miss their platform, likelky causing a poor pass. This can be for some reasons like a tracking issue (depth perception, timing etc) or because of physical limitations (platform mobility, movement etc). 

A simple drill you can do is forearm passing against a wall to focus on contact accuracy each contact. Shadow passes and other mobility drills can be good for physical limitations. We also need to be able to MOVE our body to get into a good position to contact in the Sweet Spot. We want to contact here, yes, but we also want to be in a good position to manipulate the ball. The futher the ball is away from our body, the harder it is. In emergency situations we're really extending our range to pass the ball, but the point is we need to try our best to contact here when we can and not leaning when we don't need to.

Keep in mind we CAN make good passes outside of this area (anything that contacts the ball is a platform, and if it's angled and contacted the right way it can produce a good pass), but this is an ideal spot for more consistency. We also don't need to be able to bring our arms together, as long as it's straight in the direction you want it to go on contact, and contacting both arms at the same time - for 2 arm platforms - and the ball can't go through your arm.

Quick tip for blockers! Comment below what you want to learn next ⬇️

Sometimes you will take a misstep or go a different direction. Where athletes go wrong is letting that be the end result and not doing anything about it. Even if you go the wrong way or do the wrong thing initially, there's still something you can do after that can help. This is the Double Reaction, and it applies to a lot more than blocking.

Just like our initial response, we can train the double reaction/second response as well. This can be changing directions based on the new information, or doing a second jump or changing hand positions. Remember, whatever you're already doing is the second response you've currently engrained. We can change this with reps and practicing identifying situations, mentally committing to defense and being in the moment. 

In terms of the block approach, we can practice changing directions by progressive multi change of direction work in different positions and making sure the block approach is improved, then add some reaction cues, making sure you fully commit to the first one initially to train the change in response. You can have an adjustment step if there is time or immediately stop and change directions (ideal). The better you get at identifying and performing the movement, the faster the second response will be. We can then add in specific cues and different double reactions/movements can be worked on as well (double jumps etc). 

A lot to it but hope this helps!

Tag someone who needs this! 

If you have someone that can toss or set you various balls then that's good, but for those of you that don't, you can still practice your airborne hitting! Just because you don't have a setter doesn't mean you can't work on different aspects of your hit to help improve overall hitting and serving.

Keep in mind that it's a good idea to have a solid foundation of the Spiking Sequence on the ground first. This is a good way to engrain the pattern, master the toss, master the timing of the movements and develop an accurate contact point. You can work on separating the different actions in the sequence on the ground to use the stretch-shortening cycles in the muscles involved and remember the feeling. From here you can also try to get power using it. Then we can get into different airborne drills like Jump Spike Throws, throwing a ball in the air to work on the timing of the Spiking Sequence in the air and releasing the ball at your highest point. These alone are all great ways to develop your spike without a setter for those that need work on their foundation.

When ready you can start tossing the ball in front of you, jumping and hitting with the technique work you've engrained. We want most if not all the foundation work to be complete and engrained so that it's automatic (approach technique, toss accuracy, spiking sequence etc) and you can focus on timing/adjusting, contact point, using the sequence to get power and different types of hits. If you're starting out you'll need more time developing the feel and timing of the spiking sequence in the air, which is okay. But all of these are working on your technique, timing and using it to get more power/hit better. When you eventually do get a setter, you'll still need an adjustment period but the situation will be less uncomfortable and you'll be able to adapt quicker. Basically you'll be better than if you hadn't trained. If you don't have a net you can attach a line between two walls/trees etc or mark a spot on the wall for the net height (don't hit straight at the wall when jumping) or visualize. There are ways. Be smart and safe. A lot to it but hope this helps!

Practicing this movement to add to your movement bank can be game changing for a lot of you! 

I like practicing this without a ball. Those of you on the BFV program know the Passing Movements Drill we do to help practice this pattern on both sides/different angles etc.. Start slow and then you can practice getting into these positions faster and getting out of it. You can incorporate a ball when the movement is more automatic or as your working on it gradually so you can focus on tracking and apply the movement based on the visual cues, and get into a good position to pass the ball.

We want to try to stay underneath the ball to give it some heigh and get behind it just enough so it doesn't go too far foward or behind us, especially for balls closer to the net (although sometimes behind us is ideal). Sometimes you can swing to give it some energy and direction, making sure the contact point is ideal, but also just changing your contact point and keeping it stable can be done. We can also practice sprawling and rolling out from this position. I'm in the gym without knee pads but a court and knee pads are a great great great idea 🤌 wear them

One of the ways we can build finger and overall hand strength for passing/blocking! 

We do these finger plank progressions in BFV in the open hand position. Basically this means the position you'd be in more so when receiving the ball. We need to be strong enough to withstand the impact from the ball in this position (strengthen muscles/tissues to decelerate and stop quickly) and quickly switch it to concentric (propelling the ball out of your hands). Training the isometric strength in that position doing the planks is a great way to help that. Keep in mind we still need to train the reversal strength and action, but this is a good way to strengthen around the position we'd be in to be able to quickly stop.

Of course there are levels to this and we want to start at the first level like in the video and work our way up. I love other exercises as well, like rice buckets, ExerRing exercises etc where you can build not only the fingers and hand muscles but the forearm as well. This is just one of the ways! It can also be good to strengthen to reduce the likelihood of finger injuries from passing/digging/blocking.

Level 1 (knees down) can be done for 1-3 sets 5-30 seconds depending on the athlete, phase etc

If you have a volleyball that would be ideal, but if not you can always go to the half swing sequence/resisted variation. The approach jump throws are the variation in my previous post to practice the approach and spiking sequence in the air. Ball doesn't need to be weighted and intensity in the throw doesn't need to be high! 

The half swing sequence is something I'd recommend for those learning the technique or want to maintain the pattern when away from the gym. It can be done resisted and/or at a faster rate like in the actual spike. But of course, we gotta get the actually skill in if we can. In BFV we build the technique with drills like these and progress into drills that incorporate more airborne mechanics and timing (with a set/over a net etc). We gotta have that base before progressing and take one step at a time. 

These are for quality over quantity, and I always encourage reflecting on these drills even after the fact, and not just relying on the reps and sets. In reflection you can modify certain movements and even visualize to further engrain the patterns. Like I can emhasize "pulling" with my opposite arm in the first exercise. Remember we don't want to overdo it (especially with the jumps and hits) but practice the movement, gradually increase the intensity, and learn and remember the feel for the movement. I'd go for 10 reps of 2-3 reps for the half swings, and gradually working into a maximal spike with emphasis on technique for the spikes 2-5 reps (can do per side too) and about 2- reps of the approach jump throws. Lots of rest in between. Train the pattern fresh for these, depending on the athlete/level etc. A lot more to it but hope this helps!
