Reminder of a quick tip for athletes working on their technique on the ground! 

Keep in mind this is more for athletes that need work developing the pattern of the spiking sequence. If you're an athlete that has the sequence mastered in the AIR then this may not be an issue for you. 

Too often I see athletes using these steps to hit harder instead of working on their technique that would help them in the air. Yes, it can help get the feeling of using putting your body behind the ball, but in the air, we don't get to use the ground. If the athlete is struggling with the technique, they'd probably be better off taking less steps and focus on the movement that they'd do in the air (spiking sequence) to better help them 1. Learn the pattern and 2. Learn how to generate force using the spiking sequence instead of relying on the ground.

I like a parallel or slightly staggered stance, focusing on the movement as opposed to power. Other options are seated, kneeling, standing on a stable box hitting over a net etc. The point is to learn to use the hip shift, rotation from the torso (pull back=winding, forward rotation=unwinding), to then transfer energy to the arm for it to take over. This is the Spiking Sequence that I have a lot of info on in my feed. When these movements are mastered, they can take your power further than without.

As they make the sequence more automatic, I'm generally less concerned about this. And when it comes to increasing our spiking speed, the kinetic energy we get when we toss more in front of us and step into the ball can increase our rotation and arm speeds which can be beneficial when it comes to training to increase spiking speeds (when they are ready) . But for an athlete developing, I think it can help bridge the gap between what they're doing on the ground vs in the air making sure strength, range etc are taken care of too. From there they can use the actions explosively to get more power.

Here are 2 exercises that can be great for developing explosiveness in the upper body specific to spiking and overall.

Medball slams are great for developing upper body power, but I like incorporating overhead throws with a far trajectory. Slams usually release the ball down by the chest or sometimes lower, or there can be torso flexion added which can change the release point. With the throws, we're putting ourselves in a position that is more specific to spiking. To get the trajectory and release to match, our body needs to self organize and get to the positions that will create it. This position is the "catapult" position that requires a lot of strength and adequate mobility to get in. It's the patient arm that I teach and work on in the Half spike throws and in the overall Spiking Sequence. Leon is a great example and gets into this position as the arm remains patient and comes up and around in extension and external rotation to contact the ball. Each hitter's position will vary slightly based on individual factors, but it's there. This drill is more reactive as I have the little toss up and immediate reverse out of the bottom position when I catch it, training the stretch shortening cycles in the arm and shoulder area in the Spiking Sequence. This is a double arm throw and there are single arm variations as well.

The MB reactive chest tosses are great for developiong explosive reactive power in the upper body as well. In this we're working the SSC in the chest, arm, forearms/hands by catching the ball and immediately reversing out of it. I'm starting with a little toss and lighter weight, and can overload more by increasing the height of the initial toss to bring more momentum in the catch, having the generate more force quickly to brake and reverse out of that position explosively. Other variations can be done including variations of pushup jumps. Just like in advanced lower body plyometrics, these is for more advanced athletes that have done the necessary training to prepare. Sets and reps can range from 2-5 of 1-4ish reps, rest is high! 

A lot to it, hope this helps! Let's get to work 📈

Quick tip that can go a long way for volleyball players!

This is something that can be easily implemented by athletes. Ball control is being able to manipulate the ball to your liking based on the situation. Simply being with the ball more is a great way to improve your ball control. The more you're with it, the more comfortable you get with it. The shape, how it feels. Then as you volley or bump it around a bit more you can start figuring out what happens to the ball when you do a certain action or contact a different way. We develop a better "touch". Now of course the game is much faster, but we're accumulating low level reps that can help you manipulate the ball better as you continue training. I'm doing basic volleys but you can do one arm forearm contacts, against a wall, moving around, with a partner...the list goes on. I remember walking around high school with my ball hitting it with one arm weaving through hallway traffic, sleeping with my ball, bringing it everywhere. It's good for maintaining the touch as well for more advanced players, especially if you can't get out on the court for some reason. More to it but a good one.

Simple but great.

The Flash would be unstoppable on the court ⚡️ Here are 4 drills to help fa-foom you across the court.

When thinking about quickness there are keys like movement speed, changing directions, response time to specific cues, repositioning steps, IQ and more. These are drills that attack some of them. 

Everytime we plant it's ideal to plant on the outside leg going in the opposite direction. So if we're going left but then want to go right, we stop on our left leg outside of our midline, drop the hips and quickly switch out of that position. In BFV we have the planting and cutting progressions in different directions to go over this sequence and gradually build the tolerance and technique to change directions quickly. We can train planting and cutting at different joint angles and train the SSC in these positions. We want to be fast coming out of lower and taller positions, stopping fast and switching fast off one step depending on the situation. The first 2 drills help with these and also gradually progress into more intense progressions.

The last 2 are more specific quickness drills. These cuts and movements are specific to defensive positions and responding to offensive cues. Sometimes we move one way but get crossed and need to adjust and get into position quickly. These "cuts on cues" lead up to the double reaction drill to train being able to react twice, quickly after the first one. This involves a lot of respositioning steps to get back into a good position to change directions, and be stopped on defense once contact is made. Visualization can be done here as well! Then we got tag, which is great for developing your overall movement bank which can help quickness by having more options for movement and build better hidden steps that get us into better positions. Plus it's fun! 

Sets and reps can range from 2-4 sets of 2-5 reps both sides or for time of 5-15 seconds depending on the athlete/phase etc.

Quick tip for hitting!

Being able to position our shoulder optimally key for durability and optimal hitting technique and power!

Basically the shoulder blade needs to upwardly rotate as we side bend. This is the position that the Reverse-S Curve pattern gets us in to (check out my other videos for more info). This allows us to get into a position to use the stabilizers at the shoulder joint and use the muscles involved in hitting well. It can also allow us to get optimal hitting height.

The problem is some athletes are stuck in a down and back position and aren't able to move the shoulder blade optimally (like upward rotation and protraction). This rhythm and movement is something that needs to be worked on while building the necessary strength and stabilization in muscles involved and in the way they're used in all aspects of hitting. Sometimes it can also be because of just crazy tightness around the lats that are keeping them down and not able to upwardly rotate well. Long term this can cause issues by not being able to get into certain positions, changing our technique and overusing muscles/tissues that aren't prepared well. So we need to practice the optimal torso rotation patterns, address mobility issues in the torso/shoulder/hips etc and improve strength in these areas as it relates to hitting. We do also need to address the underlying issue which ultimately can depend on the athlete, so be sure to get assessed by a professional to get advice individualized to you.

A lot to it but hope this helps! Let's get to work

A reminder of one of the simple ways to find your spacing and starting point for your regular spike approach!

Sometimes athletes don't have enough space or give themselves too much space. This can change the rhythm you have in your approach, causing you to short step your approach or jump far if you don't adjust. Knowing where you start your approach is great to be able to keep a consistent rhytmic explosive approach that you can use to jump higher and bring momentum into your spike.

Keep in mind that this is for just working on the approach at the basic and in-system level. This means that the starting point and spacing can actually be different depending on the situation, set etc. But this is a great way to take your approach and figure out how far you need to be back in a general, in-system sense.

Usually, we can take off from about 3-4 feet away from the net, but it can be more. From here, you do your spike approach (3 or 4 step depending). Then mark where your last step in the approach lands. This is the point where your first step will take place. If you want to use it as a marker to come off the pass and start the approach, the foot you push off in the approach you did away from the net will be the foot you land on the marker (if you did a 4 step away from the net (Left right planters - RLRL) you'll land with your left leg on the marker and push off and start the RLRL approach). Sometimes we don't have a lot of space off the net too. You can also use this for 2 step approaches as well as any other position on the court you want to hit from!

Great for beginners figuring out a general area to start their approach. Eventually, you develop an awareness and know intuitively where you need to be to get a good explosive approach.

This exercise is great for strengthening torso rotation, and the variations in the video get even more specific to the pattern. The underrated aspect of this exercise is learning to actually use the muscles to rotate the torso while getting separation. The separation in range allows for a good stretch-shortening cycle of the torso rotators, but we have to be able to use it. We can improve it’s usage by isolating the torso rotation. A lot of athletes focus on the arm, but the torso rotation can generate a lot of force and transfer it up to the arm if it moves in sequence. 

For some athletes that lack the strength, coordination or separation, I actually don’t want them doing the cable twist. I’d rather get them on the ground and do something like a reverse trunk twist. The Russian twist can be regressed to a seated version as well for those that aren’t ready. 

There are many aspects to this and, of course, nothing beats practicing the skill. This improves the potential, but we need to actually be able to apply this to and improve the coordination, contraction timing/speed etc of the spiking sequence. All of which are in gradual progressions in the BFV program.

Give a listen too! 3 great drills that can help improve your passing without a net!

The wall tracking drill is a great way to improve your tracking abilities. This means indentifying the tracjectory of the ball and where it's likely to end up, and pairing that with the right action/movement. This can be the legs moving toward the direction and the arms forming a platform or coming up for a hand pass based on the information. So we're training seeing what the ball is doing (trajectory) and deciding what the best thing to do is - quickly. This is KEY for passing and overall ball control. 

I start a lot of athletes with tracking movement drills when trying to improve passing or overall ball control and athleticism. When you can track better you can put yourself in a much better position to actually pass the ball. This was one of my biggest issues. I got a lot of passing reps, but I didn't know how to track and move well. When I improved this, I put myself in ideal positions to actually use my passing skills. If you don't have the movements down you can do the drill in the last clip, basically taking myself through a forward knee drop and backward-diagonal shuffle in an OPEN platform position. This frees us up to forearm pass or come up and hand pass. The entire time staying angled more toward the ball/net/target, or ending there eventually.

There are 3 basic levels to each drill if you don't have a net. First one is controlled and at a slow pace, 2nd controlled but faster to increase identification and movement speed. 3rd is random and can be different speeds. You can also attach a string across 2 points to simulate a net, it doesn't need to be perfect. Then measure out 3, 6 or 9 meters if you can for your passing area and you can have someone serve over top the string/imaginary net to apply these skills.

The idea is that you're working on the skills needed to pass. If you can have someone serve at you that would be ideal to further apply the movements and tracking drills. Then gradually ramping up the serving speeds/styles to challenge the identification and movement speeds/precision etc.

Leaves are falling so I thought I'd remind people of this! 

When I was younger I didn't have a lot of people that wanted to train as much as I did. I wanted to practice everyday, pepper every day, pass everyday, hit everyday. But volleyball is one of those sports where you need some sort of partner to serve at you, hit at you, pass with you etc. Being in this position, I didn't want to stop training. So I found ways I could work on skills myself. 

This was one I actually tried during the pandemic. Before I would toss balls behind me randomly and on the second bounce turn and sprint to wherever it was and try to scoop it up. I did this for hours it felt like. It was awesome. 

I made a lot of solo drills like this and I know theres a lot of you that are in similar situations, that's why I put them up!  Even though you dont have a partner, you can find ways to work on the skill or 👉 skills related to the skill 👈. Wall tracking drill, works in tracking that helps with passing. Platform Catches, works on absoprtion and manipulation of the ball. Around the World Passes, manupulation. Hitting Cone Drill, contact point, tracjectory and accuracy. Even just hitting the ball with technical focus is amazing. Setting into hoops. Visualization. There are SO many! 

This one is fun but I recommend learning to fall first before laying it out. It can help you practice it, but learn the best way to fall and not get injured (will go into this later). It's more for tracking and changing directions to deviations, hand eye coordination, and commiting to catching it. Too many people start and stop. Re teach yourself to GO. It'll become a habit. That leaf isn't stopping so you gotta keep going. When we can pair learning to lay it out with this our body gets into better positions to accelerate and catch/dig the ball. We know our body can get into these positions fast, we trust it and know we see it as an opportunity and can get under it better.

Other keys, the shorter the tree the less distance it is from the ground, the quicker you have to react and move to get it. We're not digging balls, but we're moving and our bodies are learning a lot that can be applied later to the skill.

The Secret Scrolls 📜

Reminder that passing, defense, and volleyball are all about angles and how to use them to manipulate the ball. 

A platform is simply anything we can get behind and under the ball. The best passers and defenders are masters at manipulating the ball because they understand how to use their platform to their advantage. They know the outcome of each touch and how to manipulate a ball based on the situation (where they are and where they want it to go). 

They are also master trackers. In order to pass and defend well, you need to be able to track well. Tracking is not just knowing where the ball will land, but also having the best movements engrained depending on the situation. This means that you know how to act based on where the ball will end up, and how you can intercept it before touching the floor while giving a quality pass. 

Too many times I get athletes that want to pass better, and immediately ask about their platform. Of course, this is what contacts the ball, but it may not be the problem. What I find is it's usually their tracking, timing, platform mobility, and/or overall movements patterns/strength. But it may also come down to their understanding of what their platform is. When I coach I help athletes understand what it is they're doing and why they're doing it. When they understand it at a deeper level, they're now moving with purpose. They can feel what it's like, and remember it. But this doesnt mean overthinking, just understanding how they can use their platform. So their platform mechanics are important, but also how you use it, tracking, timing, mobility etc are all factors that go into passing. Passing and defense depend on the ball being tracked, the timing/skill, and understanding your movements and the game will help you ADJUST your actions to different situations.

Of course there are many factors involved and it depends on the athlete and the situation! It needs to be looked at as a whole.

Keep putting in the work!

Quick tip for athletes shanking passes! 

I've talked a lot about getting behind and under for passing. Each contact is an optimal ratio of behind:under to get the angle we want, even in hand passing and one arm contacts. We're always behind and under. 

The key for ball control though is finding the optimal ratio so that the ball goes in the direction we want it to. It's all about the angles and the way we manipulate our body to use these angles and manipulate the ball.

BEHIND brings the ball forward. UNDER brings the ball up.

Keep in mind also that side passing is okay to do! I encourage it.

I sometimes see people really against side passing and push midline passing. While yes you can pass midline and track with the forehead to hand pass, side passing is a key skill to have in your bag as a volleyball athlete. 

Most times it's because the athlete shanks the ball. But the problem isn't side passing, sometimes its not side passing ENOUGH.

So, if the ball is ricocheting up and behind you, or left/right but not forward, this means you need to get more BEHIND the ball. This cuts the ball off to bring it the direction you want. In a straight pass it's less of a problem because you're already behind it. But as soon as you go outside your midline, you need to start angling your platform more to stay behind the ball. The same goes for passes you want to go more to the left or right. You need to "cut it off" more by getting behind the ball at the optimal point. 

We still need the ball to go up, so we don't need to get excessively behind the ball that it just goes straight. We need to stay under it enough as well. Now the way we can find these angles without thinking so much about it is by having a target. I love using a basketball net or setters/passers net to give the passer a target. With this they know how off they are and what they need to adjust.

Quick tip to help athletes that hit out a lot!

Where we contact the ball and how we get to that point is going to make a big difference in what happens to the ball. We only get one contact in volleyball and anything we do before that contact affects it. 

Good news is we can adjust what we do to improve what happens to it. Changing your contact point usually helps a lot of athletes who are hitting out. Contacting more in front and on top of the ball (instead of underneath and behind you) will bring the ball more down. But how we get there makes a difference as well. If we're going up and forward into the ball, the ball is going to go up and forward (ranges depending on where you contact the ball). But if we can come around and down on the ball, then this changes the direction of force into the ball making it go more forward and down. 

There is a lot to it, and many ways we can manipulate the ball, different contact and wrist actions we can do as well. What we'll want to and can do with the ball can depend also on the situation and set. There are also factors that can affect where we contact and how we get there, and drills that we can do to improve these (later post). But for now just remember that where we contact the ball and how we get there are the 2 main things that will determine what happens to the ball when hitting. Hope this helps!

The float doesn't have to be an "easier" serve. If you serve lightly then it is, but floats can do a nasty dance if done with the intent to drive the ball.

Remember a drill is about how we do something and what the intent is behind it. Anyone can just serve but the WAY we do it and what we're focusing on is key. In this drill all we're focusing on is the contact accuracy and DRIVING through the ball. This contact point is dead center on the ball with the meat of your palm. Hand is relaxed but stiff enough to resist the ball on contact. 

When driving through the ball you're basically not stopping your arm until after contact is made. Throughout the contact you're continuously trying to swing through the ball and toward your target. This gives more force to the ball and more of a linear path if contact point is good. When practicing serving more linear against the wall, you want to make sure the path is at a height that can go over the net, so mark off your net height on the wall and aim for within 1-2 feet over that.

Keep in mind we might not always just want to hit it as hard as we can for a float, and you can stop your hand on contact during a float too - but this gives it pace. We also dont always need to bring our hand all the way down, its just about going through the ball and it can stop shortly after that. We need to develop a "touch" to find the right amount and this "drive" can give the ball more pace and direction to your current float. If technique is the issue I recommend making sure you have a strong technical foundation using the spiking sequence well, and developing an accurate contact. I have a lot of content on this so check it out!

When learning a new pattern we need patience! Too many times athletes try a better technique and switch back to old habits. When we’re learning a new skill the performance may decrease initially, but then as you get better, it will go back up and surpass the previous technique. 

The other problem is they try to rush right into full speed approaches or do it in games. If you’re not prepared its not going to stick. We need the patience to groove the patterns and gradually work up to competition level speed (how we approach in game scenarios) and build strength to handle it.

The rate of progression is different for everyone. Technique should be worked on consistently when the athlete is FRESH. Some things can be done in a fatigued state, but when its the full technique rhythm, its ideal to be done in a “fresh” state. As the simpler versions (steps or approach jumps) are getting more comfortable you can start adding the skill component at a low level (approaching and spiking etc), then pick up the intensity and complexity from there.

Now this isn’t a video on how to program it within your strength training program like in my online programs, but just know that it should be gradual and increasing to “game-like” intensity as we start approaching the end of the cycle or the competitive season, making sure you have foundations of strength.

The best hitters are master adjusters!

They know how to score. One of the ways we can score more as a hitter is by putting ourselves in a better position to score. We only get one contact in volleyball and what we do before will determine the position we can get into and what happens to the ball. We can modify what we do before in order to have a better outcome. 

When it comes to hitting, it's ideal to get to the goal position contact point (highest reach, slightly in front of you). Now the contact point will change depending on what you want to do with the ball, but generally it's there.

The thing is, not a lot of athletes are good at getting to this goal position in different situations like when the set is higher, faster or off the net, or just in general. This usually looks like poor timing, jumping backwards, miscontacting the ball and leads to bad hits, not being able to see the block etc.

Good news is we can train this and get better at adjusting our approach, jump and hit to get to a good position to score. We can learn to look at the play and identify the situation, and practice adjusting our approach based on the information. If the play is faster, we can not back up as far or get out quicker. This is preparing ourselves for the most likely action. From there we can cut our approach short or change the direction based on the set. This is adjusting. Both (preparing better and adjusting) are putting yourself in a better position to jump higher, hit harder and score.

This is a drill in BFV that's meant for athletes who have worked on the basic approach/spikes and are ready to build on top of it. You can practice different footwork coming off the net or after a dig, and hitting off no approach, 1 step, 2 steps etc. If timing is the issue you can do catching to focus more on identifying the set and pairing your approach jump with it. Then add in spikes and complexity gradually.

This takes a lot of patience and time to build and get better at it, but as you advance you'll find that being able to position yourself well to hit the ball well in all sorts of situations is a valuable skill to have. A lot to it but hope this helps.

Tag someone who needs this! 

One of the common errors I see with athletes that come to me for help! Each part of the sequence is separated in range and movement. We need optimal distance between the parts, and be able to move them independently, overlapping each other to transfer force to the arm and contact the ball.

This can be because you lack the mobility or the strength and skill in the spiking sequence actions. Just like the hips and torso, we need to be able to move the torso without letting the arm get too excited. These are arm dominant swings. Sometimes in different hits we can do this of course, but if its a habit and happens regardless of the situation whenever you swing to get power, then we can be losing out on power and overall hitting efficiency. Simply just practicing the movement slowly without a ball is a great place to start! As the torso is rotating, keep the arm back! Band assistance drills can also help (in video).

I have a lot of posts on mobility and timing the sequence in my feed, so be sure to check those out as well! Accumulate the knowledge, learn and apply it to your unique self. Be patient with the process when learning a new skill! It takes time.

A reminder of one of the ways to get a more accurate contact for those consistently hitting their wrists 🏐 

The cool thing about the body is that it will adapt to something if you give it enough time and reps. If you're an athlete that would always contact their wrist or somewhere else and didn't do anything about it, chances are your body adapted to this and is now the primary way you hit. Meaning no matter what you do it will try to get back to this position because thats all it knows. Its a habit. 

The good news is we can change it by giving you a new goal and building a new pattern. Just like all skills this takes patience! Try letting go of the frustration and trusting the process. 

Getting into the new goal position and feeling what its like can cause some shifts in your movement. If your body doesnt know what its like to be in that position, its less likely to go there or trust it consistently. So we need to introduce it. Start by literally looking at the ball and seeing where you want to contact the ball. Then notice the way your body is positioned and how it feels to be in it. The goal position can vary.

Then we need to practice the pattern. In this drill some athletes will notice their arm wants to go somewhere else and this is part of their reason for inaccurate hits. Others may find they actually lose concentration, think about something else or literally look somewhere else. Practice discipline, focus, and vision here. Have a partner hold it so you can move better.

Then we gotta actually work on the skill. This isn't maximal, we need to just get used to combining the actions with the timing. This is where you can bring all the focus, visualization and feeling in. If you can make >95% accurate contacts, you can increase the intensity by 10-25%. 

Super basic but sometimes thats what you need. Be willing to go back, dial in and focus on what you need to get better and the results will show.

Quick tip for hitting and one of the drills that can be done to help!

A lot of you have seen my Reverse S Curve posts for the torso rotation. The arm follows the torso rotation pattern as well. When we pull back we have a slight side bend to the hitting side and then a side bend to the other side as the torso rotates forward. In the context of volleyball this is key for getting our shoulder and arm to move in a certain path to get in an optimal position and contact point to hit. The amount of side bend and movement within the Reverse S is different for everyone but it's there.

After the pull back and hip shift, it's ideal to have that arm come up and around on the ball as the torso rotates. This follows the torso rotation pattern. The problem is sometimes athletes don't have this pattern and can bring the arm straight forward first. Not only can this change the trajectory of the ball (depending on how we get there and where the ball is etc), but it can reduce the effectiveness of your hit.

One of the keys in hitting is separation in movement, this means moving the parts independently. It needs to be timed well so that the force can transfer up the chain and into the ball. So if the arm isn't patient, we can lose out on force transferring up the chain from the first parts of the Sequence. This drill is a controlled way to practice the elbow and arm coming around as the torso rotation is occuring, and use assistance from the band to get a feel for having a patient arm. I added in the last parts of the arm sequence but focusing on the patient arm and arm action first is a good idea. From here you can practice it without a ball, with a ball focusing on technique and gradually progressing from there.

Keep in mind also that different hits can call for different actions depending on the situation, so these are guidelines for overall hitting. A lot more to it but hope this helps!

Great contrast set for vertical jump work! This is in Phase 2 of the off-season program in BFV.

In the contrast we have a weighted explosive exercise and an assisted explosive exercise. In between we want to rest for about 30 seconds or more to get a good recovery and be explosive in the following exercise.

For these weighted jumps you can use anywhere from 0-20% bw. If you're a beginner, your bodyweight may already be enough of a load. If you don't have equipment, still trying to be explosive will still get some nice benefits from the contrast.

The assisted jumps we want to go for about 10-20% assistance. In this case it means 10-20% more jump height than your regular jump. So if you know your standing vertical is 20 inches, finding a resistance that brings you 2-4 inches higher is ideal. If you don't have a way to measure it, you can eye ball it. If you're flying to the ceiling you know it's too high. You can use marks on the wall and do a visual test by seeing how much higher your eyes get passed the mark. 

One we're resisting explosive actions with light weights to challenge the action. In the other were increasing the speed slightly to accustom the athlete to faster speeds and producing force at those speeds. A lot to it but in each of these we want to be as explosive as possible coming out of the bottom, getting a quick switch and jumping as high as possible, resetting after. 2-3 sets of 2-4 reps can be done depending on the phase/athlete! There are prerequisites for this!

Here's a simple drill that can help improve pancakes!

This is a great skill to have in the bag to still get underneath the ball. Some coaches might not like pancakes because their athletes don't get them up well. While there may be a better option in many scenarios, it's usually because the athlete just isn't good at them. If they're not good at the skill, the result won't be good. When they practice the skill, they're able to identify when it's a good time to use it and track it better to get a more accurate contact. It's also good to learn how to fall efficiently from different positions (and get back up), and practicing the motions gradually and progressively is key. If they don't have the foundational skills of falling, defense is going to be tough in general.

This is not saying that all tips should be picked up by a pancake, but it's worth having the option. We should still be able to move to the ball and try to scoop it up, and adjust mid-tracking to put yourself in a better position to get the ball up, which should still be practiced as well. If they're just dropping and falling straight down for every ball and still not getting it because they're not actually moving toward the ball, this can be a bad habit. But movement and responses are skills and can be practiced and engrained.

This is a drill to just work on the falling motion, tracking and contact accuracy of the pancake. You can practice falling from different positions as well, but this is the first level to isolate the mechanics while working on other aspects on the side like movement, ball control and falling from standing positions etc. You can progress by moving back to add speed, from a defensive position, partner tossing situation specific etc

A lot to it but hope this helps! Keep putting in the work 📈

Quick tip for passers for accurate contacts on their platform!

I talk a lot about tracking the ball to get behind and under in the direciton we want the ball to go. The sweet spot is the place I call that we actually want the ball to contact. So when we're tracking the ball, we're tracking it so that it lands here. From here you're able to manipulate the ball much better with angles and taking off/adding energy.

This is Platform Accuracy. Sometimes athletes have the right angles, but miss their platform, likelky causing a poor pass. This can be for some reasons like a tracking issue (depth perception, timing etc) or because of physical limitations (platform mobility, movement etc). 

A simple drill you can do is forearm passing against a wall to focus on contact accuracy each contact. Shadow passes and other mobility drills can be good for physical limitations. We also need to be able to MOVE our body to get into a good position to contact in the Sweet Spot. We want to contact here, yes, but we also want to be in a good position to manipulate the ball. The futher the ball is away from our body, the harder it is. In emergency situations we're really extending our range to pass the ball, but the point is we need to try our best to contact here when we can and not leaning when we don't need to.

Keep in mind we CAN make good passes outside of this area (anything that contacts the ball is a platform, and if it's angled and contacted the right way it can produce a good pass), but this is an ideal spot for more consistency, but the platform angle will depend on what you want to do with the ball and the situation. We also don't need to be able to bring our arms together, as long as it's straight in the direction you want it to go on contact, and contacting both arms at the same time - for 2 arm platforms - and the ball can't go through your arm.

Comment your questions and anything else you want to learn!

Some information to help understand separation in spiking!

Separation is one of the main principles in our Spiking Sequence System. Each part of the sequence has it in some degree in these 2 ways (range and movement). The hips and shoulders/torso is just one example, but it happens with the arm actions as well.

When athletes improve their separation in range and movement, they can access better positions in all parts of the sequence, and be able to transfer energy up the chain well and use their body optimally to get more power.

This takes a lot of practice and patience, and each athlete can lack in certain areas more than others, but I'm hoping that this info can help those looking to improve their training for spiking by understanding it more. Got a lot more in my feed on specific separation movements and range like the torso rotation and patient arm/arm action and there is a lot more to it.

The contact point and how we get there will determine the trajectory of the ball. Athletes that are hitting the ball out (more up and forward) typically have a contact point that's more underneath the ball which is making it go more up when it's hit normally.

Some athletes try to "open up" more but don't actually work through the spiking sequence!

If you're opening up like in the first demonstration, you can get more momentum into the ball, which is still better than nothing. But if we want to optimize our spiking technique and spike better and harder, it's best to learn, practice, and master the spiking sequence.

When we use the sequence well, we are opening up, but we're actually getting separation between the two parts (rib cage and pelvis). So the torso needs to rotate further back from the hips. This separation allows us to use the SSC in the torso rotators, as opposed to just twisting the body as one part. All of the movements in the sequence overlap each other and accumulate force and transfer it up the chain into the arm. So like in my posts about having a patient arm, the torso needs to be patient as well. So that when the hips shift forward, they stay back and then come forward as the hips are ending their movement. 

We use Spike Throws in our programs to practice this! Shadow spikes (without a ball) is a great way to get a feel for the movement and practice separating each of them as well. We take our time engraining this pattern and gradually apply it to actual spikes. If this is new to you, you're going to need a lot of reps! So patience and consistency are key.  A lot to it but hope this helps!

Common mistake when athletes are training for more rotational power in spiking!

"Opening up" when spiking is a great thing to do. The problem is if you're opening up as "a unit" where the whole body is rotated out and then also rotating the whole body forward as a unit toward the ball. This is because there isn't any separation between the actions. 

When we rotate the torso backward or "open up" we pull back and are stretching the torso rotating muscles. This happens optimally when the torso rotates FURTHER back than the hips. If you bring the hips back with you, you're not getting the separation to get a stretch in the muscles that power the torso rotation. You still are getting momentum into the ball, but using the Spiking Sequence optimally by separating the actions will be much better. 

When we practice spiking with throwing drills, we focus on the separation of the torso and hips and torso and arm, as well as moving them independently to transfer the force produced up the chain. For the legs and the floor, we're not able to use the floor in the air, so we practice the movements in the position we would be in the air (we can use steps to gain more momentum in the sequence though). In this way we're learning the way to move our body to produce force in the air. This is a great way to train the Spiking Sequence to help athletes improve their spiking technique and power!

Passing in the sweet spot is great to get more consistent passes!

We can technically contact the ball wherever we want as long as it's behind and under in the direction we want it to go, and we manipulate it well to give it the right amount of force. But contacting here on a straight and flat platform is a way we can get a more consistent result. So it makes sense to try to contact here as often as we can. We're also able to get a flat contact point in this area, where the arms are generally closer in most platforms to contact the ball better more often. But even if you can't get your arms to touch, you can still contact the ball with both arms if you can bring it close enough to not let the ball fall through.

As you get better at contacting the sweet spot, you're improving your ability to track the ball while being behind and under enough to get a good angle. This means you're able to get your self in a better position to pass the ball.

You can start by just passing against a wall focusing on the sweet spot. Then challenge yourself by moving around and still getting it to hit this spot. You can pass the ball forward or toward a target. Then you can speed up the tosses to challenge yourself more, or have someone serve at you focusing on contacting the sweet spot. When you're contacting accurately you can better manipulate the ball. A simple drill but it can help a lot of athletes struggling with their passing!

Here's a simple way to improve your hitting training and overall hits 🏐

If the toss is inconsistent, it can change our pattern and timing and take our focus away from the movement. So mastering the toss is a great way to help you get more consistent tosses and be able to focus on the same pattern and timing. 

For some athletes struggling with the control I get them to do 3-5 consistent tosses WITH the pull back to engrain the pattern with the situation. Then on the next one they can hit (or keep practicing the pull back).

Now of course, unless its being held in the same spot, its not always going to be the same. The idea is to set your self up for better opportunities for training the sequence and contacting in the goal position. Depending on the athlete, we also want to make sure that technique work WITHOUT the ball has been done as well. 

Then, we can also use the different tosses to learn how to adjust and get back into the goal position for a good pull back and optimal power (instead of leaning over and contacting the ball, adjust). This can give us a better sense of adjusting ourselves to contact the ball well, and carry that over to when we're approaching toward an actual set. So now instead of jumping backwards, you're able to identify the set, and position yourself or time it better to get to the goal position (with practice of course). 

So the toss can be great for getting consistent spiking and serving reps, ensuring you're setting your self up for a good use of the approach and spiking sequence (tossing in front and positioning yourself so the ball is slightly more toward your hitting side and at a good contact point) and practicing being able to adjust! Pieces to the puzzle 🧩

Here's a quick breakdown of the Spiking Sequence!

BFV members will be getting a more detailed breakdown later this week!

Pull Back - 
Pulling back of arm, torso rotating back and down (bringing arm with it), hips straighten out slightly, opposite arm higher and starting to come down/pulling away from the Pull Back, legs back/sometimes bent and overall in slight C-shape.

Hip Shift -
As pull back ends, hips shift forward with hip extension and slight internal rotation to start the momentum in the forward actions of the sequence, opposite arm continuing to come away/down, torso stays rotated back (separation in movement), pull back arm begins to change directions, legs are slightly straightening

Torso Rotation - 
As the hip shift ends and opposite arm is/almost completed, torso forward rotation occurs in reverse s curve - coming up and forward and side bending for optimal angle, opposite arm stops and comes in to counter rotate slightly and assist in torso deceleration and transfer of force, legs are straightening out, arm is patient and loaded/stretched but following torso in up and forward movement prepped from pull back phase

Arm action - 
As the torso rotation ends arm action takes over coming around with internal rotation and extension of the shoulder and arm to contact the ball, legs are fully straight and coming forward and beginnig to c shape and prep for forward flexion (can depend)

Contact point/deceleration - 
Contact is made, force was produced and transfered from the first parts of the sequence to the arm to the ball, forearm pronates slightly and c shape is used in slight flexion for additional force into the ball prepped from first parts of the sequence, deceleration begins in shoulders/arm/torso rotation with the opposite actions.

These phases are actions that produce force and overlap at different times to assist in movements/transfer force up the chain and into the ball. This is a guide and an overview of the checkpoints for the Spiking Sequence and it can look slightly different for each athlete at each phase.

Common mistake for hand passing!

A lot of athletes have troubles hand passing not because of the actual technique, but because they're tracking is off. This means that they're not able to identify where the ball is going to go and are unable to get into a good position to cut it off.

It's still a good idea to work on technique alongside, but if you can get into a better position to pass the ball, you can contact the ball better and more accurately and the pass is usually better.

I like teaching my athletes to track the ball with their forehead in order to get into a good behind and under position. They stay in their ready position and are slightly forward. We work on catching drills in this position with different tosses to work on tracking the ball, having a strong decisive direction step and adjustment steps and moving to get into a good position. I may even get them to just contact it with their head (in the ready position). This is because this is an ideal position based on average serves and the goal in passing for volleyball. We need to get the ball high enough and toward the net. Getting behind brings the ball forward and getting under brings it higher. When we get into this position we can strike it to give it more direction as well.

A catching drill like this also helps work on contact accuracy, being able to catch the ball with both hands at the same time (not fumbling). After you get comfortable with the catching and tracking, you can work on the push phase of the hand pass as well with small volleys in the direction you want to pass.

A lot to it and I'll post a more detailed video on this in the next couple of days!

Let's get to work 📈

7 of some of the different ways we can approach in volleyball!

I believe it's important to practice these types of approaches and put yourself in different situations to prepare yourself better. We often find ourselves in out of system plays or having to adjust to certain sets. Preparing for these situations with an approach or action is a skill. The more we practice this the faster we'll be able to identify the situation and prepare. The better we can prepare ourselves for this and put ourselves in a better position to hit the ball more consistently, the better the hit.

In BFV we have short approach and out of system drills, as well as in system, but you also have Freestyle time to work on different approaches and situations like these. You can customize it to your position (middle, right side, backrow attacks etc). If you don't have a setter you can visualize and practice the pattern similar to what I'm doing here, but it's ideal to eventually practice it with a setter, in game-like situations and at game-speed. 

There's definitely a lot more types. We can give ourselves a good base for different situations and develop the skill of adjusting. Hope this helps!

At home/solo hand passing drill for better tracking and contact accuracy! 

Lil' video going deeper into the drill and why this is important for passing. A lot of athletes have trouble miscontacting the ball and this can be a good initial drill to get both hands on the ball at the same time.

Adding a little volley after can be a good idea to progress a bit more, just making sure its still in the direction you were intending (it wont be the same height), just to keep the same ratio of behind:under in the pass.

I love catching drills for tracking and movement in different skills. Just remember eventually you'll want to apply this to the actual pass. But this is still a good way to work on the qualities that can help passing if you don't have a partner or just in general as a beginner. 

More to it but hope this helps!

Here's a drill and tip to help train hitting sharp cross!

We're working on the angle and turning more into the ball as opposed to away from the ball that a lot of athletes do (even hitting cross). This is for optimal transfer of force into the ball while hitting these angles, deception is a different story. This drill can be great to help teach that pattern and improve the ability to hit these well and with some pace (aside from other things that matter like contact point height and angles available).

When you only have a ball and a wall, this is great to work on hitting angles while still hitting toward the wall. We're imagining the line is the net, and if you want to work on sharp cross then ideally the line is 90 degrees to the wall you're hitting at. Then you position yourself so you face cross court in relation to this line, toss, and try to hit over the line toward the wall. We can work other angles as well, just by practicing the positioning and spiking motion to contact the ball in a way that makes it hit the wall. 

If you don't have a line you can set up a piece of tape to act as the net. And it's a good idea to have a strong technical foundation before getting to something like this. If you have access to a net and multiple balls then you can work on it by standing on a box that's ideally your jump height and hitting off a self-toss, over and over. The point is to work on the skill without being in the air to start. Of course, it does take time and you'll still need to practice it in the air, but this will help it become more automatic when hitting airborne. Also keep in mind that you should mark out 9 meters in width (simulating the width of the court) to give you a reference if your hits are in or out. Standing hits will be different, and this line=net isn't perfect, I could be more back to not hit "the net", but it's still good to have a reference and way to practice if you don't have a net.

Pieces to the puzzle! Hope this helps.

A simple progression you can do to improve pancakes for those who need it!

🔑 Learning to fall is a key skill in sport for athleticism and safety. If we can fall effectively we can be comfortable sprawling at fast speeds, be able to get up quickly and land in positions that are safe. We practice and get better at it to help prevent injuries from falling.

If we have this skill in our bag (falling and tracking to pancake or another sprawl dig), the body/mind will see this as an opportunity more often and choose it faster with enough reps. Basically we'll respond faster and have a better chance of picking it up.  Pancakes aren't the only way to pick it up, but its a good skill to have while laying it out. 

This progression starts on the floor with basics of falling from a low height and tracking/contact accuracy. You can have someone toss for you as well for all of these but this is great if don't have a partner. Then you need to get used to laying it out from a kneeling position or crouched and ready to sprawl. Then adding speed into that position gradually and starting from a defensive position. You can keep adding more speed into the sprawl and incorporate different situations, paths, deviations etc. It's also a good idea to work both hands and getting back up quickly, staying in the play! 

A lot to it but hope this helps!

Going over the main reasons why better technique in the Spiking Sequence leads to faster spiking speeds vs. arm dominant swings.

In the first spike, the @pocketradar read a faster ball. This is because I'm using the full Spiking Sequence to accumulate and transfer force. The second was lower due to primarily using my arm and not having an optimal first 3 parts of the sequence.

Keep in mind that an athletes spike can still be using the first parts of the sequence, just not as well as they could. I see this a lot when athletes come to me for their hitting. When we address the limitations (separation, strength, pattern etc), we can learn to produce more force or put ourselves in a better position to produce force and transfer it up the chain and into the ball, resulting in a faster ball when contacted accurately and quickly.

A couple of the lower body exercises I did while in Florida doing the SandX beach camp! 

When you're traveling and on a program it can be hard sometimes to do the regular routine. What's important to remember is we don't necessarily need to do EVERYTHING. Don't let not being able to do something stop you from doing what you can.

I was fortunate enough to have access to weighted plates and a barbell, but even if you don't, you can load up some books in a backpack/bag and use that. Do what you can, of course with safety in mind. 

I'm doing a Built For Volleyball workout here but keep in mind there is a time and a place for using weights while jumping! We're building explosiveness in the lower body for jumping/overall lower body explosiveness in volleyball. I've shown the skips before and they're great for improving the qualities needed for fast changes of direction. We can change the knee angle to deeper to simulate and train getting out of those deeper knee bends we find ourselves on the court. I did other exercises progressing plyos and approach jumping as well, all of which were done body weight.

Sets and reps can range around 2-4 sets of 3 jumps and 4-6 cuts left/right.

A big key is being self-aware of your level, how you feel, what you can handle, what you need etc. This takes time and practice. Everyone is different!
